Result.Abstract: Fuzzy rules have been advocated as a key tool for expressing pieces of knowledge in “fuzzy logic”. However, there does not exist a unique kind of fuzzy rules, nor is there only one type of “fuzzy logic”. This diversity has caused many a misunderstanding in the literature of fuzzy control. Result.Title: What are fuzzy rules and how to use them

Result.Abstract: Three main semantics for membership functions seem to exist in the literature: similarity, preference and uncertainty. Each semantics underlies a particular class of applications. Similarity notions are exploited in clustering analysis and fuzzy controllers. Uncertainty is captured by fuzzy sets in the framework of possibility theory. The membership function of a fuzzy set is also sometimes a kind of utility
Result.Title: The three semantics of fuzzy sets

Result.Title: Possibility Theory in Constraint Satisfaction Problems: Handling Priority, Preference and Uncertainty

Result.Abstract: A possibility measure can encode a family of probability measures. Result.Title: Possibility Theory as a Basis for Qualitative Decision Theory

Result.Abstract: This note discusses a few issues related to Yager's specificity index and the “possibilistic entropy” recently introduced by Higashi and Klir. Result.Abstract: Fuzzy logic methods have been used successfully in many real-world applications, but the foundations of fuzzy logic remain under attack. Result.Abstract: The bipolar view in preference modeling distinguishes between negative and positive preferences. Negative preferences corre- spond to what is rejected, considered unacceptable, while positive preferences correspond to what is desired. Result.Title: Bipolar possibility theory in preference modeling: Representation, fusion and optimal solutions
